Math_Problem: Find all integers $n$ satisfying $n \\geq 2$ and $\\dfrac{\\sigma(n)}{p(n)-1} = n$, in which $\\sigma(n)$ denotes the sum of all positive divisors of $n$, and $p(n)$ denotes the largest prime divisor of $n$. Instead of finding all integers $n$ satisfying the given condition, simply find $k = p(n) - 2$, where $p(n)$ is the largest prime divisor of the unique integer $n$ that satisfies the condition. Do there exist polynomials $a(x), b(x), c(y), d(y)$ such that $k + x y + x^2 y^2 = a(x) c(y) + b(x) d(y)$ holds identically? Instead of determining whether the given bivariate polynomial admits a decomposition as a sum of two products of univariate polynomials, simply find $\alpha$, where $\alpha$ is the coefficient of the constant polynomial in the unique solution to the homogeneous system obtained by requiring linear dependence among the univariate polynomials arising from evaluating the left-hand side at $y=0$, $y=1$, and $y=-1$. For a rational point $(x,y)$, if $xy$ is an integer that divided by 2 but not 3, color $(x,y)$ red, if $xy$ is an integer that divided by 3 but not 2, color $(x,y)$ blue. Determine whether there is a line segment in the plane such that it contains exactly $\alpha + 2017$ blue points and 58 red points.
